bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, March 13, 1950

div1.p: Hench informs Lawrence Reed about Wallach's involvement in the passage of a bill honoring Walter Reed. Hench questions Wallach's motivations for such action. He requests Reed's opinion in the matter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, March 13, 1950
div1.opener:
March 13, 1950
General Walter L. Reed
2810 Thirty-Sixth Place, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Reed:
div1.p:
I have no doubt that you are aware of the tentative activities of
Mr. Sidney Wallach. I had a recent letter from him enlisting my interest
in a project connected with the 50th anniversary of the conquest of yellow
fever by your father and his colleagues. I have of course great sympathy
with this project but there are two things that worry me and I think you
know enough about my loyalty to your father to permit me to talk frankly.

Mr. Wallach's proposal as outlined in H.J. Res. 396 and S.J. Res. 142,
involves the expenditure of $350,000, largely for what looks to me to be a
publicity campaign of which Mr. Wallach wishes to be the head. Mr. Wallach
says frankly: “It is, of course, my hope and that of Senator Jenner, that the
resolutions will pass and that I will head up the program of research...” I
am a little concerned about the self-interest which that seems to indicate and
it is my thought that a $350,000 memorial to your father might be better spent
or that at least a large share of it might be spent in some other more lasting
manner.

I would appreciate it if you would give me your thoughts in the matter.
I want to cooperate in every way possible but I do not want to get behind a
proposition of which you and the family do not approve and if I can help steer
Mr. Wallach into more constructive thinking, that I shall try to do.

I am taking the liberty of sending a copy of this letter to you and
one of my reply to Mr. Wallach to your father's great admirers and friends,
Generals Kean and Truby and Colonel Siler. I think that the Walter Reed
Memorial Association will have to take the activity of Mr. Wallach into account.
They will have to give it their tentative approval or stand off on the side and
if the association can add its bit to more constructive activities on the part
of Mr. Wallach, that is certainly in order.

I am sure that you realize that I will cooperate in every possible
way for any worthy venture.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
cc: Blossom Reed, General Kean, General Truby, Colonel Siler
